1030426385595228160.text:
New term: "The Modernity Trap"

1. Invent a machine or medicine
2. Find a problem to solve with it
3. Make new technology abundant and pursue a utopia
4. Realize that the side effects are worse than the original problem
5. Fix problem with more technology

Repeat the cycle.

2) You'll usually get risk calculations wrong. You’ll be very focused on keeping up with other people & not falling behind in competitive games, even in the short term.

Smart people seem to be especially at risk of such externally-driven behavior.

1089636115072593920.text: 1) You'll work on consensus ideas & on consensus career tracks. You will care a lot—much more than you realize—if other people think you’re doing the right thing. This will prevent you from doing truly interesting work.

1089636114363748358.text:
13. Be internally driven

Most people are primarily externally driven; they do what they do because they want to impress other people. This is bad for many reasons, but here are 2 important ones:

1089636113508110338.text:
This can be a piece of a business, real estate, natural resource, intellectual property, or other similar things. But somehow or other, you need to own equity in something, instead of just selling your time. 

Time only scales linearly.

1089636112006631426.text:
12. You get rich by owning things 

A huge fallacy is that people get rich from big salaries. With few exceptions, almost no one in the history of the Forbes list has gotten there with a salary.

You get truly rich by owning things that increase rapidly in value.pic.twitter.com/zJzCUYeQSz

1089636111209648129.text:
You are mostly looking for rate of improvement, so & don’t overvalue experience or current accomplishments.

I try to always ask myself when I meet someone new “is this person a force of nature?” It’s a good heuristic.

1089636110320439297.text: Get good at discovering undiscovered talent. Quickly spotting intelligence, drive, and creativity is easier w/ practice. The easiest way to learn is to meet a lot of people, & keep track of who goes on to impress you.

1089630813032009728.text:
You are mostly looking for rate of improvement, so & don’t overvalue experience or current accomplishments.

I try to always ask myself when I meet someone new “is this person a force of nature?” It’s a good heuristic.

1089630812444811266.text: Get good at discovering undiscovered talent. Quickly spotting intelligence, drive, and creativity is easier w/ practice. The easiest way to learn is to meet a lot of people, & keep track of who goes on to impress you.

1089630810578145280.text:
Define yourself by your strengths, not your weaknesses. Acknowledge weaknesses, figure out how to work around them, but don’t let them stop you from your goal. 

The best way to make up for weakness is hiring complementary teammates instead of people with your same strengthspic.twitter.com/GhVqzpKZso

1089630809844260864.text:
Develop a rep for really taking care of the people you work with. Be overly generous in sharing upside; it comes back to you 10x. 

Learn to evaluate people's gifts & put them in those roles. Push people hard enough that they accomplish more than they thought, but don't burn out.

1089630809156476929.text:
11. Build a network 

The size of the network of really talented people you know can be the limiter on what you'll accomplish

A great way to build a network is helping people as much as you can. Doing this over a long period of time is what lead to my best career opportunities

1089630807650721792.text: Most people do whatever most people they hang out with do. This mimetic behavior is usually a mistake—if you’re doing the same thing everyone else is doing, you will not be hard to compete with.

1089630806757261317.text:
10. Be hard to compete with

If what you do can be done by someone else, it eventually will be, and for less money.

The best way to become difficult to compete with is to build up leverage.

1089630806132305921.text:
People have enormous capacity to make things happen. A combo of self-doubt, giving up too early,& not pushing hard enough prevents most people from reaching anywhere near their potential.

To be willful, you must be optimistic—I've never met a very successful pessimistic person.

1089630805377339406.text:
9. Be willful 

You can bend the world to your will surprisingly often—most people don’t even try--accepting that things are the way they are.

Ask for what you want. You usually won’t get it, & often the rejection will be painful. But when it works, it works surprisingly well.

1089630804567838720.text:
8. Be bold 

it’s easier to do a hard startup than an easy startup. 

If you're making progress on an important problem, you will have a constant tailwind of people wanting to help you. Let yourself grow more ambitious & don’t be afraid to work on what you really want to.

1089630803951276032.text: You have to figure out how to work hard without burning out. People find their own strategies for this, but one that almost always works is to find work you like doing with people you enjoy spending a lot of time with.

1089630802525257731.text:
7. Work hard 

You can be top 10% by working either smart or hard. But getting to top 1% requires both.

Extreme people get extreme results. 

One of the great joys in life is finding a purpose, excelling at it & discovering your impact matters to something larger than yourself

1089630801417900033.text:
6. Focus 

Focus is a force multiplier on work.

Almost everyone I’ve ever met would be well-served by spending more time thinking about what to focus on. 

It is much more important to work on the right thing than it is to work many hours.

1089630798825877504.text:
Don’t wait too long though. 

When people get used to a comfortable life, a predictable job, and a reputation of succeeding at whatever they do, it's hard to leave it behind-- & people have an incredible ability to always match their lifestyle to next year’s salary.pic.twitter.com/CJ8sjbNiuo

1089630797986971649.text:
5. Make it easy to take risks 

Most people overestimate risk and underestimate reward.

Look for small bets you can make where you lose 1x if you’re wrong but make 100x if it works. Then make a bigger bet in that direction.

1089630797303300101.text:
Getting good at communication—particularly written communication—is an investment worth making.

1) Make sure your thinking is clear & 2) use plain, concise language.

Getting good at sales is like improving at any other skill—anyone can get better at it with deliberate practice.

1089630794530869248.text:
4. Get good at “sales” 

All great careers, to some degree, become sales jobs.

You must "sell" your plan to customers, employees, the press, & investors. This requires an inspiring vision, strong communication skills, some degree of charisma, & evidence of execution ability.pic.twitter.com/NMGW3kPjk2

1089630793742381056.text:
3. Learn to think independently 

Entrepreneurship is very difficult to teach because original thinking is very difficult to teach. School is not set up to teach this—in fact, it rewards the opposite. 

“I will fail many times, and I will be really right once” is your credo.

1089630792911863808.text:
Self-belief must be balanced with self-awareness.

I try to always listen to criticism with the assumption that it’s true, & then decide if I want to act on it or not. 

Truth-seeking is hard and often painful, but it is what separates self-belief from self-delusion.

1089630790856724482.text:
2. Have almost too much self-belief 

The most successful people believe in themselves almost to the point of delusion.

If you don’t believe in yourself, it’s hard to let yourself have contrarian ideas about the future. But this is where most value gets created.pic.twitter.com/qrtwj4Xt1h

1089630790244331520.text:
Be willing to let small opportunities go to focus on potential step changes.

One key of compound growth is that the furthest out years are the most important. 

In a world where almost no one takes a truly long-term view, the market richly rewards those who do.

1089630788327493632.text:
1. Compound yourself 

Make your career compound—most careers are linear

Each unit of work should generate more & more results. Get your leverage from capital, tech, brand, network effects & managing people

Try to add another zero to whatever you define as your success metricpic.twitter.com/lDAdwBxPIq

1089630787669028875.text:

1071443054597423104.text:
The *percentage* increase and decrease in hash rate are headline grabbing, but ultimately miss the point.

We care about the TOTAL (not relative) amount of power dedicated to proof of work.

Sound analysis must use total, not relative, as it’s crucible.

1071443053666295809.text:
5) They fail to ask *the most* important question

Most mining analysis omits the only thing we care about:

*What is the Minimum Viable Hashpower we will tolerate for Bitcoin?*

Think long and hard about this. It's what matters most.

1071443052928094208.text:
Even if they wanted to shut down as soon as they're in the red, they'll expose themselves to an avalanche of litigation.

A miner's employees, suppliers, lenders, and counterparties, are ALL creditors.

Everyone from the janitor to the landlord will sue them.

Skin in the game.

1071443052269592576.text:
Miners are businesses. And businesses are complex, entangled entities. With many stakeholders.

Unlike anonymous trolls on twitter, Bitcoin miners bear the inconvenient truth of having a physical location. 

And unless they live on a seastead, their location has a court system.

1071443051598499840.text:
But even if they had a good idea that their project was doomed, there's a simpler reason that "immediate shutdown" is laughable. 

The realities of running a business.

1071443050587676672.text:
4) Ignoring incentives. 

Much analysis makes erroneously assumes that as soon mining becomes $0.01 unprofitable on a cash (or worse GAAP! ) basis, miners will immediately shut down. 

Literal lol.

Miners have long-term incentives outside the cash cost of 2-week mining time.

1071443049929158656.text:
3) Viewing mining statically, not dynamically

Hardware & electricity are cost inputs. But so is the behavior of OTHER miners.

The cost to mine a bitcoin is an *ITERATIVE* calculation. It depends on your % of network hash power. Which constantly changes when other miners act.

1071443049270657025.text:
Do we assume stupidity? That Jihan Wu is fecklessly posted at one of his farms, pacing anxiously, ripping cigarettes, & furiously refreshing prices on coinmarketcap? 

Or assume intelligence? That the biggest players are leveraging financial instruments to mitigate risk of ruin.

1071443048582840320.text:
Let's look at other commodity & capital-intensive industries like airlines, oil, & agriculture:

Far from unsophisticated rubes, big players in those worlds HEAVILY use complex financial instruments. Hedging with futures, swaps, & other derivatives. 

Miners are no different.

1071443045885849602.text:
2) Assuming miners are stupid

As the great @benthompson often says: 

"Assuming stupidity is a good way to miss tons of factors that influence decision-making."

Reading most analysis, you'd think miners are helplessly lost at sea in the crypto tempest. 

Wrong.pic.twitter.com/XX38n8s5tm

1071443045332213760.text:
If 90% of all miners disappear, it's unclear whether that's a problem.

If 90% of all hash power disappears, it almost certainly is.

1071443043230892033.text:
Mining is security. And security comes from hash power. 

We care about the true “cost” for the minimum acceptable amount of HASH POWER. 

Not costs for average or median miners.

We know a small number of players controls a large amount of hash power. What matters is THEIR cost.pic.twitter.com/UGFNPmQanU

1071443041536356353.text:
Now let's debunk the FUD.

1) The model for "expensive" mining is elegant in theory but nonsense in practice

The flaw is *who* & *what* gets measured. Measuring the cost for the "average miner" or "median miner" is nonsense. We don't actually care about either.

1071443040814944258.text:
Before we debunk, let's start with the following premise:

A) The job of a miner is to secure the network

B) Miners are mercenaries, paid by network participants to do their job. 

Therefore:

C) Hash Power revolves around Price, Price does not revolve around Hash Power

1071443039980269568.text:
I see these 5 common & fatal errors:

1) The model for "expensive" mining is elegant in theory but nonsense in practice

2) Assuming miners are stupid

3) Viewing mining statically, not dynamically

4) Ignoring business realities

5) Failing to ask *the most* important question

1063908997718306816.text:
The core idea of Incerto: 

We live in a world of uncertainty. And the more uncertainty there is in the the system, the more paranoid we have to be.

1063908996413829121.text:
The core messages of Antifragile and Skin in the Game: 

1) Things change with scale. Singapore is not a small China. A big blowup is worse than many small blowups.

2) In the dynamic, changing (real) world, your "rational" strategies are completely different than in static one.

1063908994870325249.text:
The difference between A) offering 6 people $1bn each to play 1 shot of Russian Roulette vs  B) offering 1 person $6bn to play 6 times.

No matter how much you value your life, A is Rational. B is not.

Trading wisdom: Take all the risk you can, but make sure you’re in tomorrow.

1063908993947656192.text: The concept of path-dependence hasn't made it into decision psychology yet. If you go bust on day 28, there is no Day 29.

1063908993050050560.text:
If you walk into a casino, and you have a small probability of blowing up. No matter WHAT your edge is, you will blow up. 

Because you can’t say “I’m going to blow up and then get rich.” you get rich, then blow up. Sequence matters.

1063908992290877440.text:
Things viewed statically have completely different properties than things viewed dynamically.

You only understand this if you are  math wiz (no one is) or if you have skin in the game.

1063908990227226625.text:
On ergodicity & path dependence:

Sequence matters. If you wash your pants, then dry them, then  wear them you get different results than if dry your pants, then wash them, then wear them.

Don't get soaked.pic.twitter.com/lb3qNtunUN

1063908989447094272.text:
Science is not about proving, it's about disproving.

Science is a process, not a result.

Science is minority rule. Even if 300 Nobel Prize winners agree on something, one experiment can prove them wrong.

1063908987492540416.text:
On Black Swans:

No matter how many white swans you see, you can never disprove the existence of black swans. 

But there's asymmetry. if you see just one black swan, you prove its existence. 

No evidence of cancer is not evidence of "No Cancer"pic.twitter.com/IGyOJMRNGZ

1063908986582376449.text:
Tocqueville wanted to protect the minority from the majority. 

In modernity, we may have to do the opposite.

1063908984384643072.text:
The Intolerant Minority Rule:

Less than 0.3% of juice drinkers are kosher. But 100% of juice is kosher. 

Why? 

A non-kosher person will drink a kosher drink, but a kosher person will never drink a non-kosher drink.

The intolerant minority rules the world.

1063908983520530436.text:
Whenever the government could debase the currency, they would. 

This is why there were money changers in the temple during the days of Christ. 

Religions were no fools. They wanted the hardest, soundest money possible

1063908982476161024.text:
The Lindy Effect.

The discovery that if a broadway play survives for 200 days, it will survive for 200 more. 

Government issued currencies have never been Lindy. History tells us that.

1063908979229827072.text:
infrequent, higher risk is Bad Asymmetry

Falling 100 meters off a ledge is more than 100x as harmful as falling 1 meter off a ledge 100 times.pic.twitter.com/KPCWBIVCTP

1063908978550337537.text: Bottoms up tinkering (aka trial & error) is Good Asymmetry. It will always outperform top-down design. When you use trial & error, you have an IQ of 1,000. You can double down where you see success and cut bait where you fail.

1063908977703047168.text: Bad asymmetry is the Bob Rubin Trade. When you keep the upside but transfer the downside risk to someone else, like the anonymous taxpayer.

1063908975303958528.text:
Good Asymmetry vs. Bad Asymmetry.

Good asymmetry is a call option. 

If you'll make more in the upside than you lose in a downside, you'll do very well, provided you survive.pic.twitter.com/AiD0mpdHce

1063908973135437824.text:

1063908972187533313.text:
Many look at inequality by how easy it is to rise. But the best metric is how easy it is to fail. 

The average lifespan in the S&P 500 is 11 years. That's down from 60 years. 

And their Price / Earnings ratios are higher. 

We live in Extremistan.

1063905553615773696.text:
More importantly, people will accept inequality if the rich person is willing to take risks.

People are upset by a rent seeking, bloodsucking CEO making 50x what a worker makes.

But they're never upset by Steve Jobs, who had skin in the game.pic.twitter.com/2VxcsrNMfr

1063905552550559749.text:
The way we talk about "inequality" is wrong.

We're measuring it statically, not dynamically. 

If you compare the Forbes list from 1982 to today, there's less than 10% overlap in names. 

60% of Americans spend 1 year in the top 10%. 

12% spend 1 year in the top 1%

Inequality?

1063905548372975616.text:

A failed entrepreneur is more honorable than someone who's never been an entrepreneur.

"Come back with your shield, or on it."pic.twitter.com/Vak2TKXh0a

1063905547412475904.text:
Virtue signaling in action:

When a hotel asks you to "save the planet" by reducing water consumption...

1063905544656834560.text:
If you went to the circus and the trapeze artist had a parachute, that's not risk. 

There's no virtue without risk. 

Any virtue that doesn't entail some kind of sacrifice or cost isn't a virtue at all.pic.twitter.com/tEb2AeuGbG

1063905543721533441.text:
A lot of virtues are fake because anyone can signal them costlessly.

But risk taking is real. You cannot fake risk-taking. The essence of Skin in the Game.

1063905542832365570.text:
Today, we have civilian warmongers, leading from the rear.

But if you want to cause people to die, you should be exposed to it. It's the natural balance of society.

1063905541741785088.text:
Never in history (other than modern times) did we have leaders who took less physical risk than the common person.

Being a "Lord" meant you assumed an obligation to protect your people in exchange for high status. 

Skin in the Game.

1063905539904757760.text:
The Golden Rule (do unto others...) sucks.

I could force you to eat Lebanese food just because I liked it.

The Silver Rule is more robust. Don't do unto others what you don't want them to do unto you.

1063905539057426432.text: Skin in the Game: Thou shalt not have the upside without bearing the downside risk.

1063905537614667776.text:
1982 banks lose more money in a SINGLE YEAR than they'd made in the entire history of banking. 

And yet, bankers are still rich. They know how to hide and socialize their losses.

1063905536754761729.text:
Flash forward to 2008. Citibank is insolvent. Who bails it out? Not Bob Rubin. But the taxpayers. Our dentists and bus drivers.

Bob Rubin did not show up with his checkbook, to make things right. He simply resigned.

1063905536016551936.text:
The Bob Rubin Trade: when no skin in the game hurts society.

Bob Rubin collected $120mm in salary while chairman of Citigroup. 

There, he stuffed the bank for of industrial grade hidden risk. There was no edge to the trades, they just blew up infrequently.

1063905535207055362.text:
Skin in the Game (symmetry) via Hammurabi's code:

If the architect builds a house, and it collapses, the architect shall be put to death.

You cannot hide risk then walk way.

1063905531839070208.text:
Many academics, economists, & bureaucrat compare themselves to pilots, but they're wrong. 

Pilots have skin in the game. The bad pilots are all under water. Dead. 

There’s a selection mechanism that doesn’t depend on the judgement of other pilots.pic.twitter.com/HPURTGyLwB

1063905527355371521.text:

1063905526445236224.text:
Here's why journalism is going to die. 

Because journalists simply try to impress other journalists. They don't work for the reader.

So they become a monoculture that's very vulnerable.

They have no accountability to reality, only each other. And their business is doomed.

1063905525589573633.text:
Plumber A's compensation isn't determined by the government calling up other plumbers and asking how big Plumber A's bonus should be. 

And if you show up to the dentists's office with your teeth intact, but leave with half of them missing, it's easy to judge competence.

1063905524759085057.text:
In trading, you're only judged by a P&L. If you lose money, no matter how nice you are, you're out of a job. if you make money, not matter how nasty you are, you have a job. 

 Plumbing and  Dentistry are similar:

1063905523999932416.text:
Being judged by survival is a different game than being judged by your peers. 

Industries where you're only judged by peers (academia, journalism, restaurants) will rot. 

In business, you don't want to impress your peers. The only person you want to impress is your accountant.

1063905521642733568.text:
The Expert Problem:

There are 2 kinds of professions. Those where the experts have no clue what they're talking about, & those where they do.

The "Expert Problem" doesn't exist in industries like weather forecasting. If you repeatedly fail predict the weather, you don't last.pic.twitter.com/J3kNL6s6vu

1063905515867185153.text:
In theory, there's no difference between theory and practice. 

In practice, there is. 

Academics lecturing traders on how to run their business is like nuns lecturing prostitutes on how to run theirs. 

It's two different worlds.pic.twitter.com/7wANfLppIk

1061627622977867776.text: Leaks empowered the regime’s enemies with damning facts. But more importantly, they induced the regime to stop communicating internally, a kind of calcification of its circulatory system more deadly than any outside enemy."

This is a fundamental tension I see in crypto:

Binary vs. gradient. Black & white vs. sliding scale.

It appears everywhere:
-network security
-privacy
-scalability

1051531711341842433.text: The oligopoly of the internet is built on a conflict of interest between owners & users. "Crypto networks are supposed to turn users into owners, erasing the conflict"

1051531709857112064.text:
"[the current equity system] works so well that we complain that internet giants align with shareholders too much and users too little–sometimes trading user privacy or wellness for higher advertising returns."

True that.

1051531708720443392.text:
"What’s best for the value of equity won’t always be what’s best for the token."

This an incredibly important point. The cryptoasset ecoystem seems rife with conflicts of interest and lacking in ways to address them and align incentives.

1051531707747377152.text: I'm also unclear what a 'claim on the aggregate value of the current supply' means?

1051531706665197571.text:
"These equity-like expectations are not legally enforced." 

If they're not legally enforced, they're not claims. This may seem like splitting hairs, but definitions matter here.

1051531703947268097.text:
Here's an easy way to tell if you have a claim: if your facts were accurate, could you sue (a) someone, (b) somewhere, to (c) give or do something? If yes, then you have a *claim* (aka a 'cause of action).

Cryptoasset claims fail (a), (b), & (c). They're not claims on anything.

1051531700059148290.text:
"A cryptoasset is a pro-rata claim on the aggregate value of the current supply of a cryptoasset"

I disagree. Within the world of law & property rights, the word *claim* has a specific definition. It means a "legal entitlement" to something...pic.twitter.com/OaBxOXso2q

1051531694912794624.text:
"What you get with equity"

Equity is a pro-rata claim on the *equity* value of a co., not the *enterprise* value. The difference? Enterprise value includes debt. 

And equity is a *residual claim.* An equityholder gets whatever is leftover (residual) after creditors get paid.pic.twitter.com/06tI1iKNsc

1051531689598562305.text: While this is a useful and directionally correct framework of tokens vs. equity, I disagree with some of the details (reasonable minds can differ of course).pic.twitter.com/gI6LLfGEhl

1048932358748037120.text: "Cryptography will ineluctably spread over the whole globe, and with it the anonymous transactions systems that it makes possible."

1048932355828842498.text: "Cypherpunks deplore regulations on cryptography, for encryption is fundamentally a private act.  The act of encryption, in fact, removes information from the public realm.  Even laws against cryptography reach only so far as a nation's border and the arm of its violence.

1048932353345814529.text: "We don't much care if you don't approve of the software we write. We know that software can't be destroyed and that a widely dispersed system can't be shut down."

1048932350548164608.text: "Cypherpunks write code. We know that someone must write software to defend privacy, & since we can't get privacy unless we all do, we're going to write it. We publish our code so that fellow Cypherpunks may practice & play with it. Our code is free for all to use, worldwide."

1048932349495468033.text: "People have been defending their own privacy for centuries with whispers, darkness, envelopes, closed doors, secret handshakes, and couriers.  The technologies of the past did not allow for strong privacy, but electronic technologies do."

1048932346785873920.text: "Information does not just want to be free, it longs to be free.  Information expands to fill the available storage space.  Information is Rumor's younger, stronger cousin; Information is fleeter of foot, has more eyes, knows more, and understands less than Rumor."

1048932344697110528.text: "Privacy in an open society also requires cryptography.  If I say something, I want it heard only by those for whom I intend it.  If  the content of my speech is available to the world, I have no privacy.  To encrypt is to indicate the desire for privacy,"

1048932343749197825.text: "...Until now, cash has been the primary such system.  An anonymous transaction system is not a secret transaction system.  An anonymous system empowers individuals to reveal their identity when desired & only when desired; this is the essence of privacy."

1048932342591606784.text: "Therefore, privacy in an open society requires anonymous transaction systems..."

1048932341320695809.text:
Here's where the hammer drops. The dystopia of a "cashless" digital financial system that's surveilled:

"When my identity is revealed by the underlying mechanism of the transaction, I have no privacy.  I cannot here selectively reveal myself; I must _always_ reveal myself."

1048932340301484032.text: "...In most cases personal identity is not salient. When I purchase a magazine at a store and hand cash to the clerk, there is no need to know who I am"

1048932339399712769.text:
Suggested rules of the road given this new reality:

"We must ensure that each party to a transaction have knowledge only of that which is directly necessary for that transaction.  Since any information can be spoken of, we must ensure that we reveal as little as possible...

1048932338237943809.text: "...If many parties speak together in the same forum, each can speak to all the others and aggregate together knowledge about all parties.  The power of electronic communications has enabled such group speech, and it will not go away merely because we might want it to."

1048932336581193729.text:
Electronic communication (speech) can be *aggregated* & make once-private information public. Which is fine, but a fundamental departure from history.

"The freedom of speech, even more than privacy, is fundamental to an open society; we seek not to restrict any speech at all...

1048932330352627712.text:
"Privacy is necessary for an open society.

Privacy is the power to selectively reveal oneself to the world"
